title: SWE Engineer Technical Rubric

dimensions.name: communication
dimensions.description: Clarity, structure, and ability to articulate trade-offs.

levels.description: Unclear narrative, missing steps, hard to follow.
Explains key steps but lacks structure or precision.
Clear, structured explanation with good trade-off discussion.
Concise, polished explanation with strong technical clarity.

dimensions.name: problem_solving
dimensions.description: Ability to frame the problem, choose strategies, and adapt under constraints.

levels.description: Weak framing or incorrect approach.
Reasonable approach but limited optimization or alternatives.
Solid strategy with trade-offs and optimization awareness.
Elegant, scalable approach with strong insight and adaptability.

dimensions.name: correctness_reasoning
dimensions.description: Soundness of reasoning, invariants, and proof of correctness.

levels.description: Incorrect or lacks reasoning.
Some reasoning but incomplete or shaky.
Clear correctness reasoning with key invariants.
Rigorous, complete, and convincing proof.

dimensions.name: complexity
dimensions.description: Accuracy of time/space analysis and optimization decisions.

levels.description: Missing or incorrect analysis.
Basic analysis with minor errors or omissions.
Accurate analysis with reasonable optimization choices.
Thorough analysis with strong optimization and scalability.

dimensions.name: edge_cases
dimensions.description: Identification and handling of edge cases, constraints, and failures.

levels.description: Misses critical edge cases or constraints.
Covers some edge cases, incomplete handling.
Covers major edge cases and constraints well.
Comprehensive coverage and robust handling.

dimensions.name: data_structures_selection
dimensions.description: Choice of appropriate data structures and understanding of their properties.

levels.description: Poor or inappropriate data structure choice.
Reasonable choice but misses better alternatives.
Good choice with justification of trade-offs.
Optimal selection with deep understanding of properties.

dimensions.name: algorithm_design
dimensions.description: Ability to design efficient algorithms and recognize patterns.

levels.description: Unable to design a working algorithm.
Working solution but inefficient or brute force.
Efficient solution with good algorithmic thinking.
Highly optimized solution with novel insights.

dimensions.name: system_design_scope
dimensions.description: Ability to scope and decompose large-scale systems.

levels.description: Misses major components; narrow scope.
Identifies key components but misses interactions.
Good decomposition with clear component boundaries.
Comprehensive scope with well-defined interfaces.

dimensions.name: scalability_tradeoffs
dimensions.description: Understanding of scaling challenges and architectural trade-offs.

levels.description: No consideration of scale.
Acknowledges scale but limited solutions.
Identifies bottlenecks and proposes reasonable solutions.
Sophisticated understanding with multiple scaling strategies.

dimensions.name: database_design
dimensions.description: Schema design, indexing strategy, and query optimization.

levels.description: Poor schema or no indexing consideration.
Reasonable schema but missing key optimizations.
Good schema with appropriate indexes and query planning.
Optimal design with advanced techniques (sharding, denormalization).

dimensions.name: api_design
dimensions.description: RESTful/API design principles, resource modeling, and versioning.

levels.description: Poor resource modeling; inconsistent patterns.
Basic REST understanding but misses best practices.
Clean resource design with good status code usage.
Excellent API design with versioning, pagination, and error handling.

dimensions.name: security_awareness
dimensions.description: Identification of security risks and mitigation strategies.

levels.description: No security consideration.
Acknowledges basic threats (auth, injection).
Identifies multiple threat vectors with mitigations.
Comprehensive threat modeling with defense-in-depth.

dimensions.name: concurrency_handling
dimensions.description: Understanding of parallel execution, race conditions, and synchronization.

levels.description: No awareness of concurrency issues.
Identifies race conditions but limited solutions.
Good understanding of locks, atomics, and deadlock prevention.
Advanced concurrency patterns; lock-free or immutable designs.

dimensions.name: testing_strategy
dimensions.description: Approach to testing including unit, integration, and edge cases.

levels.description: No testing consideration.
Basic unit tests for happy path.
Comprehensive testing including edge cases and integration.
Test-driven approach; property-based or contract testing.

dimensions.name: code_quality
dimensions.description: Code organization, readability, maintainability, and best practices.

levels.description: Spaghetti code; poor naming and structure.
Working but messy; some organization.
Clean, readable code with good abstractions.
Exemplary code; modular, extensible, and self-documenting.

dimensions.name: debugging_methodology
dimensions.description: Systematic approach to identifying and fixing defects.

levels.description: Random guessing; no structured approach.
Basic debugging with print statements.
Systematic hypothesis testing with tools.
Efficient root cause analysis with preventive measures.

dimensions.name: technical_tradeoffs
dimensions.description: Ability to weigh competing concerns (performance, maintainability, time).

levels.description: Ignores trade-offs; picks arbitrarily.
Acknowledges trade-offs but limited analysis.
Explicit trade-off analysis with clear rationale.
Sophisticated evaluation of multiple dimensions.

dimensions.name: technical_leadership
dimensions.description: Guiding technical decisions and mentoring others.

levels.description: No evidence of technical leadership.
Occasionally influences technical decisions.
Consistently guides architecture and reviews.
Sets technical direction; mentors effectively.

overall_scoring: Compute the overall score as the average of all dimension scores, scaled to 0-100 and rounded.

questions: Explain how a hash map works internally to a non-technical stakeholder.
Walk me through your approach to the previous coding problem.
How would you document a complex API for other developers?
Design an algorithm to find the most frequent element in a stream of data.
How would you approach debugging a performance regression in production?
Design a system to detect duplicate files on a file system.
Prove that your binary search implementation always terminates correctly.
What invariants does quicksort maintain during partitioning?
How would you verify that a distributed system is eventually consistent?
What is the time and space complexity of your LRU cache design?
Analyze the complexity of your solution to the N-Queens problem.
How does your algorithm scale with input size? Where are the bottlenecks?
What edge cases would you test for a function that validates email addresses?
How does your rate limiter handle burst traffic and clock skew?
What happens in your distributed system when a node fails during a transaction?
Why would you choose a hash table over a binary search tree for this problem?
What data structure would you use to implement an autocomplete system?
Compare and contrast arrays, linked lists, and skip lists for a leaderboard.
Design an algorithm to find all palindromic substrings in a string.
How would you implement a spell checker with suggestions?
Design an algorithm to schedule meetings in the fewest conference rooms.
Design a URL shortener service. What are the major components?
How would you architect a real-time chat application?
Design the backend for a photo sharing social network.
How would you scale a database that has become read-heavy?
What are the trade-offs between vertical and horizontal scaling?
Design a caching strategy for a globally distributed application.
Design a schema for an e-commerce platform with products, orders, and customers.
How would you index a table with frequent range queries on timestamp?
When would you denormalize a database schema intentionally?
Design REST endpoints for a task management application.
How would you version an API to avoid breaking existing clients?
What status codes and error formats would you return for validation failures?
How would you prevent SQL injection in your application?
Design an authentication flow for a mobile app.
What security considerations are important when storing user files?
How would you implement a thread-safe counter across multiple servers?
Design a producer-consumer queue with backpressure.
What happens when two users concurrently edit the same document?
How would you test a distributed system with network partitions?
What unit tests would you write for a function that parses user input?
How do you test that a cache invalidation strategy works correctly?
What makes a function 'clean' and how would you refactor a large one?
How do you name variables, functions, and classes for readability?
When is it appropriate to use design patterns?
A service crashes only under load. How do you debug it?
Memory usage grows slowly over time. How do you find the leak?
A bug disappears when you add logging. What do you do?
When would you choose consistency over availability, and vice versa?
How do you balance shipping quickly with maintaining code quality?
What are the trade-offs between microservices and monoliths?
How do you advocate for a technical direction when others disagree?
Describe how you've helped a junior engineer improve their coding skills.
How do you ensure technical decisions are documented and shared?

easy.description: Fundamental concepts, single data structure, straightforward implementation.
easy.example: Reverse a linked list, valid parentheses, two sum.

medium.description: Multiple considerations, optimization awareness, some trade-offs.
medium.example: LRU cache, course schedule, number of islands.

hard.description: Complex algorithms, system design, deep trade-off analysis, scalability.
hard.example: Design distributed rate limiter, median of two sorted arrays, serialization.

scoring_tips: Score each dimension independently based on the candidate's response.
Look for explicit reasoning, not just the final answer.
Consider the candidate's ability to recognize when they don't know something.
Higher scores require both correctness AND depth of understanding.
Note if the candidate improves their answer after probing questions.
common_pitfalls: Candidate jumps to implementation without problem framing.
Candidate cannot explain why their solution works (intuition vs rigor).
Candidate ignores constraints (memory, time, scale) in their design.
Candidate cannot identify the limitations of their approach.
probing_questions: Can you prove that this always works?
What happens when input size grows to 1 billion?
How would you handle failure in this component?
What alternative approaches did you consider?
What's the bottleneck in your design?

dimensions.name: scale_consciousness
dimensions.description: Designing for Google-scale traffic and data.

levels.description: No consideration of scale.
Acknowledges scale but proposes impractical solutions.
Reasonable scaling strategies with identified bottlenecks.
Sophisticated distributed systems thinking at planetary scale.

dimensions.name: operational_excellence
dimensions.description: Designing for operability, monitoring, and fault tolerance.

levels.description: No operational considerations.
Acknowledges monitoring or logging.
Designs for observability and graceful degradation.
Comprehensive operability strategy including runbooks and alarms.

dimensions.name: enterprise_considerations
dimensions.description: Designing for enterprise customers (compliance, integration, supportability).

levels.description: No enterprise considerations.
Acknowledges enterprise needs but limited depth.
Incorporates backward compatibility and integration.
Comprehensive enterprise design with compliance and support.

dimensions.name: user_experience_craftsmanship
dimensions.description: Attention to UI/UX details and performance smoothness.

levels.description: No UX consideration.
Acknowledges usability but surface level.
Designs for responsiveness and intuitive interfaces.
Obsessed with pixel-perfect, fluid, accessible experiences.

dimensions.name: privacy_by_design
dimensions.description: Minimizing data collection and protecting user privacy.

levels.description: No privacy consideration.
Acknowledges privacy but reactive.
Proactively minimizes data collection.
Privacy-first architecture with on-device processing.
